problem:
In this problem, $a$ and $b$ are integers, such that $a \ge b.$

If $a+b\equiv 2\pmod{10}$ and $2a+b\equiv 1\pmod{10}$, then what is the last digit of $a-b$?
solution:
To determine the residue of $a\pmod{10}$, we can subtract $a+b$ from $2a+b$: \begin{align*}
a &= (2a+b) - (a+b) \\
&\equiv 1 - 2 \\
&\equiv -1 \\
&\equiv 9 \pmod{10}.
\end{align*}Then we know that $9+b\equiv 2\pmod{10}$, so we can solve for $b$: \begin{align*}
b &\equiv 2-9 \\
&\equiv -7 \\
&\equiv 3 \pmod{10}.
\end{align*}Finally, we substitute to obtain $$a-b \equiv 9-3 \equiv 6 \pmod{10},$$and so the last digit of $a-b$ is $\boxed{6}$.
model_solution:
Step 1: Subtract the second congruence from the first congruence, so that we eliminate the variable \( b\), obtaining the congruence \(a \equiv 1\pmod{10}\).
Step 2: Since $a \equiv 1\pmod{10}$, we know that $a$ is congruent to $1$ modulo $10$, which means $a$ leaves a remainder of $1$ when divided by $10$.
Step 3: 
From $a \equiv 1\pmod{10}$, since $a \ge b$, the possible values of $a$ that are greater than or equal to $b$ and satisfy the given congruence are the integers that leave a remainder of 1 when divided by 10, which are $a=1, 11, 21, 31, 41, 51, 61, 71, 81, 91$.
Substitute $a=1, 11, 21, 31, 41, 51, 61, 71, 81, 91$ into both of the original congruences and determine which of the resulting congruences for $b$ is satisfied for each value of $a$.
Step 4: 
We can substitute $a=1$ into the first congruence to obtain $1+b\equiv 2\pmod{10}$, which simplifies to $b\equiv 1\pmod{10}$. Substituting $a=1$ into the second congruence gives $2(1)+b\equiv 1\pmod{10}$, which simplifies to $b\equiv -1\pmod{10}$. These two congruences are not consistent, so $a=1$ does not satisfy the original congruences.
Next, we can substitute $a=11$ into the first congruence to obtain $11+b\equiv 2\pmod{10}$, which simplifies to $1+b\equiv 2\pmod{10}$, and therefore $b\equiv 1\pmod{10}$. Substituting $a=11$ into the second congruence gives $2(11)+b\equiv 1\pmod{10}$, which simplifies to $2+b\equiv 1\pmod{10}$, and therefore $b\equiv -1\p
Substitute $a=21$ into both congruences to obtain $21+b\equiv 2\pmod{10}$, which simplifies to $b\equiv -1\pmod{10}$; and $2(21)+b\equiv 1\pmod{10}$, which simplifies to $b\equiv 9\pmod{10}$. These two congruences are not consistent, so $a=21$ does not satisfy the original congruences.
Substitute $a=31$ into both congruences to obtain $31+b\equiv 2\pmod{10}$, which simplifies to $b\equiv -1\pmod{10}$; and $2(31)+b\equiv 1\pmod{10}$, which simplifies to $b\equiv 9\pmod{10}$. These two congruences are not consistent, so $a=31$ does not satisfy the original congruences.
Substitute $a=41$ into both congruences to obtain $41+b\equiv 2\pmod{10}$, which simplifies to $b\equiv -1\pmod{10}$; and $2(41)+b\equiv 1\pmod{10}$, which simplifies to $b\equiv 9\pmod{10}$. These two congruences are not consistent, so $a=41$ does not satisfy the original congruences.
Substitute $a=51$ into both congruences to obtain $51+b\equiv 2\pmod{10}$, which simplifies to $b\equiv 9\pmod{10}$; and $2(51)+b\equiv 1\pmod{10}$, which simplifies to $b\equiv 1\pmod{10}$. These two congruences are not consistent, so $a=51$ does not satisfy the original congruences.
Substitute $a=61$ into both congruences to obtain $61+b\equiv 2\pmod{10}$, which simplifies to $b\equiv 9\pmod{10}$; and $2(61)+b\equiv 1\pmod{10}$, which simplifies to $b\equiv 1\pmod{10}$. These two congruences are consistent, so $a=61$ satisfies the original congruences.
